clinical_study.brief_title: Immunogenicity, Safety, Tolerability and Ability to Prime for Memory of Meningococcal C Conjugate Vaccine in Healthy Children
clinical_study.official_title: A Phase III, Multi-Center, Open-Label, Controlled, Randomized Study to Evaluate the Immunogenicity, Safety, Tolerability and the Ability to Prime for Memory of Chiron Meningococcal C Conjugate Vaccine When Administered to Healthy Infants as One Dose Given at 2 or 6 Months of Age With a Booster at 12-16 Months of Age, in Comparison to Two Doses in the First Year of Life, Given Two Months Apart, With a Booster at 12-16 Months of Age; and in Comparison to One Dose Given at 12-16 Months of Age

brief_summary.textblock: Immunogenicity, Safety, Tolerability and Ability to Prime for Memory of Meningococcal C Conjugate Vaccine in healthy children

detailed_description.textblock: The aim of this study is to investigate the immunogenicity offered by MenCC vaccine when administered in different schedules at different years of life: 2 doses in the first year of life given 2 months apart (at 2 and 4 months of age), with a booster in the second year of life, or 1 dose in the first year of life (at 2 or 6 months of age), with a booster in the second year of life, or only 1 dose in the second year of life.

primary_outcome.measure: Demonstration of non-inferiority of memory antibody response after 1 dose of MenC Vaccine administered to healthy infants at 2 to 6 months of age and as first, second or third dose in the second year of life,as measured by rBCA.

secondary_outcome.measure: Evaluation and comparison of antibody response and its persistence in terms of GMT and percent responders, as measured by rBCA.

arm_group.arm_group_label: Group 4: 12-16 Months (1 dose in the second year of life)

intervention.description: Meningococcal conjugate vaccine, active comparator. Groups 1 to 3 were given a booster dose in the second year of life at 12-16 months of age
intervention.arm_group_label: Group 4: 12-16 Months (1 dose in the second year of life)

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- healthy infants
Exclusion Criteria:
- known hypersensitivity to any vaccine component
- significant acute or chronic infections
- previously ascertained or suspected disease caused by N. meningitidis
- previous household contact with an individual with a positive culture of N. meningitidis serogroup C
